posts.name: Justin| Alum|FRC 3035
posts.cooked: I was looking at old diagrams of robot power distribution and noticed the backup battery. This seems really great, how come it isn't allowed or used anymore?

posts.name: Justin| Alum|FRC 3035
posts.cooked: A screenshot of an example is provided below. This image, taken on April 20, 2025, at 10:24 PM, features a filename indicating its origin and dimensions, along with a description of its size and format.

posts.name: EricH
posts.cooked:
You gotta get the old fogeys for that one. First, understand why it was needed, and then why it went away. If you fit that description, you’re in luck—or maybe not.  

Way back in the early 2000s, there were occasional issues with robots losing most of their power but not all. A common problem involved robots spending most of their time wandering the field, only to die and wander again, their batteries presumably toast. If the controller voltage dropped too low, strange things happened, and the E-Stops often failed because the controller couldn’t send a proper signal. Notably, the controller was connected directly to one of the power distribution board’s ports, protected by a full breaker.  

This issue was addressed in the mid-2000s, around 2004 when it first appeared. Innovation First International, Inc. developed a backup battery port. You could charge your 7.2V battery, plug it in, and the controller and radio would function enough to send signals and shut down properly.  

Why did this solution disappear? When the 8-slot cRIO was introduced in 2009, it came with a more advanced power distribution board. Specifically, this PDB was designed to power the cRIO via a dedicated branch circuit, ensuring sufficient voltage regardless of the battery’s condition. Subsequent versions like CTRE’s Power Distribution Panel (PDP), REV’s Power Distribution Hub (PDH), and PDP2 followed suit, placing the RIO on a dedicated power point that remained one of the last components to lose power during a malfunction.  

In short, the solution isn’t required anymore for safety reasons, as modern power distribution board circuitry now provides equivalent protection.
The PDP2 is nothing more than a hunk of copper with some ports on it. Would this cause the same problems to happen again that warranted the backup battery?

posts.name: Peter Johnson
posts.cooked: No, because the RoboRIO has internal voltage regulation and well-behaved undervoltage lockout logic that cleanly disables things before it completely loses power.

posts.name: Joshua J
posts.cooked: When the PDP, PDH, and PDP2 arrived, they all followed the same pattern: they connected the RIO (in its various forms) to a dedicated power point, which was typically the first to lose power during brownouts or shutdowns. However, newer models now feature dedicated ports operating at battery voltage with built-in brownout protection and advanced internal power management systems to keep the RIO operational longer.

posts.name: Mike
posts.cooked: Oh man, really putting out the old-timer bat-signal for this one. When we first used multiple CIM-motor drivetrains, we often experienced nasty voltage drops, particularly during high-torque moments like turning or pushing. This issue was exacerbated by using old batteries across multiple seasons with multiple deep-discharge and recharge cycles. Back then, the robot controller was powered directly from the battery, with the radio also drawing power from this IFI robot controller. If the battery voltage dropped below about 7 volts for even a brief moment, the robot controller would reset, forcing us to wait for it to recover and reconnect to the field. While this didn’t take as long as modern systems like the RoboRio and VH radio to restart, it still left us without control during those moments. A backup battery ensured the controller wouldn’t reset during these voltage drops, allowing us to maintain some functionality despite the issues. Without that backup, the robot wouldn’t have had consistent 12V power to the speed controllers, and we’d have been triggering 40-amp breakers frequently. Today, if you use an outdated battery and push the system hard enough to cause voltage drops, the RoboRio/driver station’s built-in brown-out protection disables the motor outputs to protect itself from resets, which can take minutes to resolve. This sacrifices the robot’s ability to move while preserving the system’s stability. The same protection applies here; if the voltage drops too low, the robot loses performance, but the RoboRio stays operational.

posts.name: gurellia53
posts.cooked: I have some fleeting memory of the backup battery also being tied to some specific functionality, possibly related to servo power. I may be completely misremembering, but it really feels like our '07 robot couldn’t deploy ramps (using a servo) without a backup battery.

posts.name: usbcd36
posts.cooked: This particular PDB was built to specifically power the cRIO off of a dedicated branch circuit that ensured enough voltage was supplied to the cRIO almost regardless of actual battery voltage. Because the RoboRIO has internal voltage regulation, this was a critical component. Back then, switching voltage regulators were expensive. The cost of low-RDS-on MOSFETs and integrated regulator controllers had significantly decreased during the 2000s and 2010s. "Just tack on a second battery" was a common solution at that time. I recall hearing that the backup battery was tied to specific functionality, possibly servo power. This setup provided power to the PWM port power rail, where servos connected. While it wasn't essential for Victor motor controllers, which didn't use the power pin, it was crucial for servos.
